Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Research and Education on Evolving Surface Patterns in Thin Films

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Number: CMS-0547409
Proposal Title: CAREER: Research and Education on Evolving Surface Patterns in Thin Films
Principal Investigator: Rui Huang
Performing Organization: University of Texas at Austin

Abstract

Of both fundamental and practical interest, the proposed research project will develop physics-based mathematical models and efficient simulation approaches to understand the dynamics of pattern formation in thin-film materials. Specifically, two research tasks are proposed: Task A will develop a kinetic model to simulate the evolution process of wrinkle patterns in hard films on soft substrates, and Task B will develop a mathematically similar model to simulate self-assembly of quantum dots in heteroepitaxial systems. The objective is to develop a quantitative understanding of the pattern evolution dynamics in both systems and to explore novel engineering techniques to control the patterns. The proposed research will have a significant impact on the making of devices for technological applications. The proposed education activities include curriculum development, new tools for education, research experience for undergraduates and students from underrepresented groups, outreach activities directed to K-12 students and teachers as well as the general public.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hard films on soft substrates are common in nature, where wrinkles occur in scales varying from a few nanometers (in cell membranes) to hundreds of kilometers (on the surface of the earth). Modern technology has developed a broad range of applications with integrated hard and soft materials. Through this project we have investigated on the dynamics of surface wrinkle evolution in thin elastic films on viscoelastic substrates. Physics-based theoretical models and numerical simulations are developed to predict various wrinkle patterns. Our study  reveals significant surface effect for nanoscale  wrinkling of ultrathin polymer films with films thinner than 40 nm. In collaboration with an experimental group at National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), we have explored wrinkling as a metrology tool for measuring elastic and viscoelastic properties of polymer thin films. The research of this project has led to a new research direction on swelling induced surface instability in hydrogel-like soft materials.

A total of eight graduate students, one postdoc, and one undergraduate student have participated in this project. Among them, two have graduated with PhD degrees and two with Master's degrees. This project has also enabled continual development of a new course on Thin Film Mechanics by incorporating the research results. Over the years the PI has also developed new tools for teaching a undergraduate class on Aerospace Materials. A new web site, iMechanica.org, has also been used for educational purposes to reach a broader audience.

 


Last Modified: 05/20/2011
Modified by: Rui Huang

In collaboration with an experimental group at National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), we have explored wrinkling as a metrology tool for measuring elastic and viscoelastic properties of polymer thin films. The research of this project has led to a new research direction on swelling induced surface instability in hydrogel-like soft materials.
